keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding affecting five states.
The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzuba, reported 65 people still missing.
The states most affected are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.
Thousands of military personnel from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to assist in search and rescue and aid distribution.
Over 100,000 homes have been affected, with some buildings near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
More than 80% of electricity supply has been restored across the five states, with around 263,000 users previously without power.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated there were no early meteorological warnings indicating the severity of the rainfall.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding in Mexico, caused by the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, has resulted in at least 64 fatalities and 65 people still missing across five states, with Veracruz, Hidalgo, and Puebla suffering the worst impacts. The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso, leading to landslides and widespread destruction of homes and infrastructure. Thousands of military personnel have been deployed to assist in search and rescue and deliver essential supplies, while nearly 80% of electricity has been restored. President Claudia Sheinbaum and CNPC chief Laura Velazquez Alzua emphasized the lack of early meteorological warnings, raising concerns about Mexico's disaster preparedness systems.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
